relationships.notes: Visits Jesus under cover of darkness to discuss rebirth and later joins Joseph in preparing Jesus’s body with an extravagant mixture of spices.
Raises a legal objection during the council’s attempt to arrest Jesus, insisting that the law hear a person before judgment.
Partners with Joseph of Arimathea to claim and bury Jesus’s body, providing spices while Joseph supplies the tomb.

traits.identity_and_status: Introduced as a Pharisee and a ruler of the Jews, a teacher of Israel who comes to Jesus.
traits.nighttime_visit: Visits Jesus by night to discuss his signs and teaching, prompting Jesus’s discourse about being born from above and the work of the Spirit.
traits.misunderstanding_and_instruction: Misunderstands Jesus’s metaphor of new birth in literal terms, allowing the Gospel to unfold themes of spiritual rebirth and heavenly origin.
traits.cautious_defense: Later speaks up in the Sanhedrin, arguing that their law does not judge a person without first hearing from them, signaling a partial, cautious defense of Jesus.
traits.participation_in_burial: Joins Joseph of Arimathea in preparing and burying Jesus’s body, bringing a large mixture of myrrh and aloes, an act of costly honor and devotion.
traits.narrative_profile: Moves across the Gospel from cautious nighttime inquirer to public participant in Jesus’s burial, embodying a trajectory of emerging but ambivalent faith.
